newsitem.title: INDIA: Commodities - Wheat, rice grab focus in India.
newsitem.headline: Commodities - Wheat, rice grab focus in India.

text.p: Wheat and rice will hold the Indian commodity trade's focus as the government tries to ensure enough supplies of foodgrains at cheaper prices, traders said on Sunday.
"There's a gap between demand and supply in foodgrains," said Mulraj Tanna of commodities traders Jamnadas Madhavji International Ltd.

But, sizeable state purchases from farmers following a good summer wheat harvest may mean the government will import less than an initially planned two million tonnes for 1997/98 (April-March), government officials said.
State agencies are expected to buy about 11.1 million tonnes from farmers in 1997/98 against 8.2 million last year, they said.
The government buys wheat from farmers to build up buffer stocks and can then control prices by releasing grain through its distribution system.
Tanna said domestic demand for rice had been growing in the recent past due to a drop in state purchases of wheat.
Exporters said demand for lower grades of Indian rice picked up last week as buyers signed contracts in anticipation of further price rises at the end of the season.
But exports of higher grades of rice had been facing stiff competition from Vietnam, Pakistan and Burma, Tanna said.
"Once the new crop comes some time in September/October Indian exports will become competitive," Tanna said. "But everything depends on the rain gods."
The four-month June-September monsoon season set in after a week's delay, causing a mild concern among farmers as they prepared for sowing across the country.
"Monsoon has covered most parts of the country, though it is still weak in some regions," said Navin Shah, president of the Bombay Oilseeds and Oils Exchange.
Shah said the arrival of rains and enough imports of palmolein had a sobering effect on domestic edible oil prices.
He said traders had booked up to 80,000 tonnes of palmolein for delivery in each of the months of June and July.
"Shipments of imported palmolein are arriving at regular intervals," Shah said.
In the week to Friday, groundnut oil prices moved in a narrow range of 355/356 rupees per 10 kg. Palmolein fell three rupees to 266 per 10 kg.
In soybean, the focus has shifted from soymeal exports to preparations for sowing as pre-monsoon rains arrived in central India which accounts for the bulk of the country's production.

According to the Soybean Processors" Association of India (SOPA), the area under soybean cultivation is expected to rise to 5.7 million hectares in the 1997/98 season (November/October) from 4.0 million in the current year.
SOPA has cautioned farmers to sow soybean only after their lands received a rainfall of 7.0-8.0 cm.
"The soil should have enough moisture for good seed germination," a SOPA official said. Pre-monsoon rains had so far brought in a rainfall of about 4.0 cm.
SOPA has set a soybean production target of 5.7 million tonnes for 1997/98 against the current season's 4.0 million.
The monsoon made a good start in most cotton growing areas.
"As of now, the cotton situation is very satisfactory," said C.H.Mirani, former president of the East India Cotton Association, a trade representative organisation.
Output in almost 70 percent of India's 9.0 million hectares of area under cotton is vulnerable to rainfall fluctuation.

Cotton prices remained steady in the week to Saturday, despite a shortage of ready stock. Traders said the bulk of the current season's record crop of 16.78 million bales (one bale is 170 kg) had already been marketed.
Gujarat Sankar-4 was quoted at 17,500/22,000 rupees per candy (355.56 kg) and Punjab F-414 was unchanged at 2,080/2,090 rupees per maund (37.32 kg). (Conversion $1.00=35.80)
